    • Constructor Detail

      • ElasticEmailClient

        public ElasticEmailClient(ElasticEmailClient.ElasticEmailProperties props)

        Create an instance of a client that can speak to the Elastic Email service in the cloud.

        As for its statefulness, the reference 'props' that you pass it is kept as a member variable, but that's all. No other state is kept. So you can keep a single instance of this class around, or re-instantiate it with the same props if you wish next time you need it.

        Parameters:
        props - ElasticEmailClient.ElasticEmailProperties credentials needed to communicate with the Elastic Email API

    • Method Detail

      • sendEmail

        public TransactionId sendEmail(java.lang.String channel,
                      java.lang.String fromEmail,
                      java.lang.String fromName,
                      java.lang.String toEmails,
                      java.lang.String subject,
                      java.lang.String bodyText)
                        throws java.io.IOException

        Sends a plain text email.

        This will send an outbound email via Elastic Email. Note that you must have already set up Elastic Email via their website to send emails from a particular domain, and your "from" fields need to match that domain.

        Parameters:
        channel - This is an arbitrary string so that you can run reports at Elastic Email and bucket your outbound email statistics. Pass null to ignore.
        fromEmail - This is the email address that the email will be "from".
        fromName - This is the human readable name of the person (or bot) the email will be "from".
        toEmails - This is a semicolon separated list of email recipients.
        subject - This is the Subject line of the email.
        bodyText - This is the plain text body of the email.
        Returns:
        A transactionId string is returned, which can be passed to #getStatus(String) to check the status of your message delivery.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - The Elastic Email API is over HTTP. If any communication goes awry, you'll get an IOException.

      • sendEmail

        public TransactionId sendEmail(java.lang.String channel,
                      java.lang.String fromEmail,
                      java.lang.String fromName,
                      java.lang.String toEmails,
                      java.lang.String subject,
                      java.lang.String bodyText,
                      java.lang.String bodyHtml,
                      java.util.List<AttachmentId> attachmentIds)
                        throws java.io.IOException

        Sends an email with both plain text and html versions available for the client to choose to display. Attachments can be made as well.

        This implementation was updated 10/26/2011 per this: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2793150/how-to-use-java-net-urlconnection-to-fire-and-handle-http-requests

        Parameters:
        channel - This is an arbitrary string so that you can run reports at Elastic Email and bucket your outbound email statistics. Pass null to ignore.
        fromEmail - This is the email address that the email will be "from".
        fromName - This is the human readable name of the person (or bot) the email will be "from".
        toEmails - This is a semicolon separated list of email recipients.
        subject - This is the Subject line of the email.
        bodyText - This is the plain text body of the email.
        bodyHtml - This is the html version of the email body. Pass null to not supply an html version of the body.
        attachmentIds - If you have any attachments, list them here. They must be uploaded in advance by calling uploadAttachment(InputStream, String).
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - The Elastic Email API is over HTTP. If any communication goes awry, you'll get an IOException.

      • uploadAttachment

        public AttachmentId uploadAttachment(java.io.InputStream data,
                            java.lang.String filename)
                              throws java.io.IOException

        Upload an email attachment.

        Attachments must be uploaded in advance of sending out email messages. Each uploaded attachment is assigned an AttachmentId, which will be referred to when sending a message with an attachment.

        Parameters:
        data - Supply a binary of your attachment, in the form of an InputStream.
        filename - Provide a name for your attachment. Use the obvious file extensions, as they will likely help on the client side when the attachment is received.
        Returns:
        The AttachmentId returned will be used in sendEmail(String, String, String, String, String, String, String, List) to specify the attachment(s) to be used for the message.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - The Elastic Email API is over HTTP. If any communication goes awry, you'll get an IOException.

      • getStatus

        public MailerStatus getStatus(TransactionId transactionId)
                       throws java.io.IOException,
                              ElasticEmailException

        Poll the status of an outbound message.

        Parameters:
        transactionId - This is a TransactionId that you were given when you made the call to send the outbound message.
        Returns:
        MailerStatus, which contains counters for number delivered, bounced, etc. But for now, this class (ElasticEmailClient) is setup to only send out messages one at a time, so the value returned in one of the fields of MailerStatus should only be a 1.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - The Elastic Email API is over HTTP. If any communication goes awry, you'll get an IOException.
        ElasticEmailException
